abstract: Tailoring morphology of the support is considered to be an effective way to tune the physicochemical properties of the catalysts. Herein, we have developed a rational strategy combining of electrospinning, hydrothermal and annealing method for the first time to design well-defined hierarchical double-walled Co3O4 hollow nanofibers (CHNFs). This special tailored complicated wall structure leads to a large specific surface area, increased substrate adsorption, and improved mass transfer of reactive species, which can be employed as an ideal support for loading high-dispersed ultrafine Pt nanoparticles (PtNPs). Such a PtNPs/CHNFs catalyst exhibits an excellent catalytic activity and stability toward CO oxidation.

author_highlights.sentence: Well-defined hierarchical Co3O4 hollow nanofibers (CHNFs) are fabricated for the first time.
CHNFs possess large specific surface area, and improved mass transfer of reactive species.
CHNFs have been used as an excellent support of Pt nanoparticles toward CO oxidation.
